options: Go with the opinion of the admitting consultant
Seek a second opinion from a consultant not currently involved in the case
Have a discussion with the family about the difference of opinion amongst medical staff
Agree a timeframe with the family, stating that treatment will be withdrawn if improvement is not seen
Transfer the patient to another hospital
Continue full treatment until the situation is resolved
Ask the family whether they want to withdraw care
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor working in the Intensive Care Unit. A 66-year-old man has been admitted following an emergency abdominal aortic aneurysm repair. He has failed to make any progress since admission and is still requiring ventilatory support and haemofiltration. There is a disagreement amongst the consultants about whether it is appropriate to withdraw treatment. How should this situation be handled?

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
The GMC give the following guidance:
'You should always give consideration to seeking a second opinion. You must seek a second opinion in cases where you are not sufficiently experienced or knowledgeable, or where there is significant disagreement within the team about clinical aspects of a patient's care.'

As stated in the GMC guidelines a second opinion should be sought here. You should be honest with the family about the difference of opinion and why you are seeking a second opinion. If this is done correctly it will give the impression that you are going to great lengths to ensure the most appropriate care for their loved one. Treatment should be continued until a decision is made.
question:
You are a ST1 doctor working in the Intensive Care Unit. A 66-year-old man has been admitted following an emergency abdominal aortic aneurysm repair. Treatment should be continued until a decision is made.

GMC94
Confidentiality guidance

options: Self-prescribe some anti-depressant medication
Do nothing
Leave the Foundation Programme
Take more time off
Obtain support from close family if possible
Consult the GMC guidance on reporting changes to health
Consult the NICE guidance on reporting changes to health
See your GP
questions:
You are a junior doctor about to start your last rotation of the year in renal medicine. Over the preceding few weeks you have noticed that your mood has been low. Your concentration while at work is poor and you find yourself tired and stressed for most of the day. This is starting to have an effect on the quality of your work and you have called in sick on more than one occasion which has not seemed to help. What do you do?

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
The GMC recommends that if you have a change in your physical or mental health then you should obtain advice from a registered healthcare professional. In this situation the most appropriate is likely to be your GP. The GMC has guidance on its website of what should be disclosed to them when thinking about health problems. It is often not much about the condition itself, but how it impacts on your ability to work. Having supportive family, friends and colleagues who you can confide in is always useful. However, you may not always feel able to tell them about problems such as this.

NICE are not involved in this kind of problem. Taking time off in some situations may help, but not in this one. You should not self-prescribe. The best thing to do is get healthcare advice from another doctor, ideally the GP. Doing nothing and leaving the Foundation Programme is avoiding the problem.

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
question_notes:
The GMC recommends that if you have a change in your physical or mental health then you should obtain advice from a registered healthcare professional. In this situation the most appropriate is likely to be your GP. The GMC has guidance on its website of what should be disclosed to them when thinking about health problems. It is often not much about the condition itself, but how it impacts on your ability to work. Having supportive family, friends and colleagues who you can confide in is always useful. However, you may not always feel able to tell them about problems such as this.

NICE are not involved in this kind of problem. Taking time off in some situations may help, but not in this one. You should not self-prescribe. The best thing to do is get healthcare advice from another doctor, ideally the GP. Doing nothing and leaving the Foundation Programme is avoiding the problem.
title: GMC guidance: doctor's health
body:
The General Medical Council (GMC) makes it explicitly clear that you should not rely on your own judgement of the risk posed by your health to your patients. They state that this should be done by an 'appropriately qualified healthcare professional'. You must seek and follow their advice on any changes to your work necessary. In this case therefore, the only appropriate choice is to consult occupational health.

Risks posed to patients by your own health
  • 'If you know or suspect that you have a serious condition that you could pass on to patients, or if your judgement or performance could be affected by a condition or its treatment, you must consult a suitably qualified colleague.'
  • 'You must follow their advice about any changes to your practice they consider necessary.'
  • 'You must not rely on your own assessment of the risk to patients.'

Good Medical Practice, domain 2, subsections 28-30, GMC 2013
concept: Regarding a change in your physical or mental health as a doctor, it is often not so much about the condition itself, but how it impacts on your ability to work

options: Break the bad news about her husbands diagnosis over the phone
Tell the wife that you need to tell her husband first
Tell the wife that you will have to gain permission from the husband to speak to her
Tell the wife that the medical team is currently investigating
Tell the wife that she should come to the hospital urgently to discuss the findings
questions:
You are a junior doctor on a gastroenterology ward. A patient was admitted and has been under investigation for colorectal cancer. You have seen the results of initial investigations this morning, which are suggestive of a diagnosis of a metastatic colorectal cancer. The patient's wife rings the ward soon after this asking for an update on her husbands condition.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Unless your patient has given consent prior to you speaking to the wife, this could possibly be a difficult conversation, as by following GMC guidelines you should not part with information unless consent has been given. Therefore, telling the wife that you will have to gain consent form her husband first (3) is the best course of action. This deals with the issue of confidentiality and will mean that you will then be able to answer the questions that she has to ask. An option that could also be appropriate would be to tell the wife that the medical team is currently investigating (4). This does not deal with the issue of confidentiality, hence it being less preferable than option 3, however it does update her as to what is going on. Furthermore, only the results of initial investigations have returned, so explaining that the team is investigating is a fair summary, as no conclusive results have returned thus far.

Telling the patient's wife that you need to tell the husband first (2) is incorrect, as consent can be sought from your patient. However, this is a better option that telling the patient's wife to urgently attend the hospital to discuss the findings (5). This options would possible endanger his wife's safety, as she is likely to rush to the hospital, and would cause unnecessary worry, as the results back are only initial investigations and are not conclusive.

Breaking the bad news about her husbands diagnosis over the phone (1) is the worst option. The patient does not have a definitive diagnosis as yet, and this method breaks confidentiality and involves breaking bad news over the phone, which is a poor method of doing so.

options: Speak to your consultant about it
Continue as usual, you'll be in the same position next year
Speak to your educational supervisor about the scenario
Leave any outstanding jobs for the on-call team and leave at 5pm
Speak to the registrar about it
questions:
You are an ST doctor working on a busy respiratory ward. Your registrar delegates a lot of his jobs to you meaning you end up staying much later than he does every day. You rarely leave the hospital before 7pm whereas he always leaves at 5pm and sometimes earlier.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
A direct conversation with the registrar will be useful in this situation to let him know how you feel (E).

Your consultant (A) is in a better situation than your educational supervisor (C) to know what is happening in your team and may be able to liase with the registrar.

Whilst the on-call team is not designed to take on jobs that haven't been completing during the day, it is important that doctors do not work significantly over their assigned hours as this may lead to burnout and handing over jobs may be necessary in some circumstances (D).

Continuing as usual is a poor choice and will lead to fatigue which could put your patients at risk (B).

options: Arrange a meeting next week to see how he is doing
Advise him to go and see his General Practitioner
Speak to his consultant the next morning discussing your concerns
Suggest that he takes some sick leave and go on holiday
Prescribe him a SSRI and follow him up on a week-by-week basis
questions:
You are an ST1 doctor in surgery. You are having a meal with one of your ST1 colleagues after work. He says that he has been feeling down recently. He doesn't really know, he just doesn't seem to enjoy the things that used to interest him.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Your colleague is exhibiting signs of depression and is possibly reaching out for help. This is one of the rare situations where the answers you give in the exam probably mirror what you would do in real life.

The most appropriate response is to suggest that he arranges an appointment with his General Practitioner. This would allow him to see a person skilled in assessing patients with depression and allow appropriate treatment and monitoring.

Providing practical support by arranging to see your colleague next week is the next best answer.

Suggesting that he takes some sick leave doesn't really change the underlying problem.

Prescribing for yourself or colleagues is dangerous and should never be done.
question:
You are an ST1 doctor in surgery. You are having a meal with one of your ST1 colleagues after work. He says that he has been feeling down recently. He doesn't really know, he just doesn't seem to enjoy the things that used to interest him.

GMC94
Confidentiality guidance

options: Put in a formal complaint to the trust
Contact the British Medical Association for advice
Speak to your Educational Supervisor about the problem
Secretly record his comments using your smart phone as evidence for future disciplinary hearings
Ask the consultant for a chat to discuss how his remarks are affecting your confidence
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor in medicine and have recently started a new rotation. During the ward rounds your consultant frequently refers to you as 'the idiot' and constantly makes disparaging remarks about your intelligence and competence. These comments are affecting your confidence and you are starting to dread seeing him. Whilst he occasionally makes similar remarks to other doctors on the firm he seems to direct them much more frequently to you.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This kind of behaviour is unfortunately still prevalent due to the hierarchical nature of medicine. If deliberate it clearly represents a form of bullying, However, some doctors may (mistakenly) see it as part of the normal 'banter' and 'ribbing' of new doctors.

The best response in this situation is E. Whilst it would clearly require significant courage for an ST1 doctor to discuss their concerns with the consultant directly, it is nearly always better to discuss problems directly first.

The next best response is C. Your Education Supervisor will know the consultant and may tell you that such comments, whilst inappropriate, are not unusual. This may reassure some doctors. They may also be able act as an advocate on your behalf and speak to the consultant about his behaviour.

Putting in a formal complaint straight away (A) is not the best response as it does not allow the consultant to put their side across and may mean that you would have to switch firms due to the breakdown of the working relationship. If however, the situation does not change after appropriate warnings it may be your only recourse.

The British Medical Association (B) can provide advice but are not in a position 'on the ground' to change what is happening. They would, however, have more of a role if you ever decided to put in a formal complaint.

Secretly recording conversations (D), which may include confidential patient information, is a very bad idea and would likely result in disciplinary proceedings against you.

options: Apologise and explain that there are no doctors of the opposite gender available at the current time
Ask a nurse of the opposite gender to perform the examination
Perform the examination with a chaperone despite patient reservations
Complete your assessment without the examination
Ask if the patient would like to wait to see a doctor of the opposite gender
questions:
You are a GP trainee seeing a patient with a 4 week history of abdominal pain. As part of your assessment you need to perform an intimate examination. The patient states they would like a doctor of the opposite gender to perform the examination. All of your colleagues of the opposite gender are busy.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This question covers the Good Medical Practice domain, establishing and maintaining partnerships with patients.

The best option is to apologise about the situation and explain that there are none of your colleagues of an opposite gender currently available.

After this it is helpful to ask if the patient would like to wait and be seen during her visit.

Completing the assessment without the examination may be the best option if there are no appropriate colleagues around, and you feel that by waiting for one your patient's care would be compromised.

Asking a nurse to perform the examination is not advised, as he/she may not be trained in examination, and their findings may not be reliable.

Performing the examination against patient wishes, even with a chaperone, is completely wrong and could be seen as assault.

GMC, Good Medical Practice 2014, Paragraphs 46-49
question:
You are a GP trainee seeing a patient with a 4 week history of abdominal pain. As part of your assessment you need to perform an intimate examination. The patient states they would like a doctor of the opposite gender to perform the examination. All of your colleagues of the opposite gender are busy.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
question_notes:
This question covers the Good Medical Practice domain, establishing and maintaining partnerships with patients.

Asking a nurse to perform the examination is not advised, as he/she may not be trained in examination, and their findings may not be reliable.

Performing the examination against patient wishes, even with a chaperone, is completely wrong and could be seen as assault.

GMC, Good Medical Practice 2014, Paragraphs 46-49

options: Immediately inform the consultant + speak to the patient if requested to do so by the consultant
Take no further action to prevent alarm to the patient
Complete a clinical incident form
Reflect about the incidence in your e-portfolio
Immediately inform the consultant + tell the patient what happened later in the day and apologise
questions:
You are a F2 doctor in cardiology. You have been signed-off to perform central lines by yourself. Whilst attempting to insert an internal jugular central line you accidentally flush the line with around 1 ml of air. The patient suffers no apparent adverse effects.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Luckily the patient appears not to have come to harm from the error. Despite this, it is important to be open and handle the situation as you would for any other error. The consultant in charge of the patient's care should be notified in case he/she wants to take any further action. The patient should be given an explanation and apology. Following this, a clinical incident form should be completed. This allows frequent errors to be recognised so that systems may be changed.

Adding a reflective entry to your e-portfolio is better than doing nothing but does not tackle the immediate situation.

Taking no action is a poor option as it does not address any of the issues.

options: Report your colleague to the GMC
Speak to your colleague about what you have seen
Discuss the issue with your registrar
Inform infection control
Reprimand your colleague for failing to abide by the rules
questions:
You are a junior doctor on a busy hospital ward. You have noticed over the past few weeks that your fellow doctors on the ward does not comply with infection control policies of being bare below the elbows, as she frequently has her sleeves rolled down and wears jewellery.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The observation of your colleague not abiding by the bare below the elbows policy is something that needs addressing, with this being a policy that is in place to reduce the risk of patients contracting hospital acquired infections. Therefore, the most appropriate action in this scenario is to speak to your colleague about what you have seen (2). This may be something that they are not aware of and you speaking to them about it may help them in realising that they can improve their practice when it comes to this policy.

Discussing the issue with your registrar (3) is the next most appropriate option. This option will also deal with the issue of your colleague not abiding by the policy. However, this option involves escalating the issue to another member of your medical team, which given the available options is unnecessary. This is a better option than escalating to infection control (4) immediately, however.

Reprimanding your colleague for failing to abide by the bare below the elbow policy (5) is a poor response to the scenario. Despite your colleague failing to follow infection control procedures, reprimanding a colleague is not something that you should do. This undermines them and may create tension between members of the medical team. However, this is a more preferable option than reporting your colleague to the GMC (1), which is a severe over-reaction to the scenario.
question:

options: Ignore it, research is just as important.
Inform her that this is unprofessional and she should attend if she signs in.
Seek advice from your educational supervisor.
Speak to another colleague about the situation for advice.
Inform the director of education.
questions:
A colleague of yours regularly signs in to the lunchtime teaching sessions but then leaves before the lectures start to work on research projects in the library.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This is unprofessional and goes against GMC guidelines on honesty and integrity, therefore, you should inform your colleague of this fact (B). The GMC states that doctors should always act with this attributes in mind. Your educational supervisor is also a good source of advice (C). Taking advice from your peers when you are unsure is a reasonable option (D).

Informing the director of education is an option, however, it is quite heavy-handed for something such as this (E). Ignoring a breach of GMC guidelines is a poor choice (A).

GMC. Good medical practice. Maintaining trust.
question:
